awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Greener Processes for the Sustainable Development of Bio-Based Polyesters
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of green separation and processing strategies to produce bio-based polymers is beneficial to ensure environmentally sustainable materials for future generations. Current monomer production methods typically use petroleum and require hazardous processes. Biomass offers diverse alternate starting materials for polymer chemistries. However, current strategies for isolating monomers from biomass and their polymerizations are limited and often not sustainable in practice. The development of sustainable bio-based polymers requires a holistic approach that tackles key sustainability issues associated with monomer sourcing and extraction, polymer creation, and end-point feedback. This project seeks to utilize residual biomass sources, green extraction techniques, and appropriate polymer syntheses to incorporate structurally rigid monomers (i.e. pentacyclic triterpenols) into the backbones of polymer networks and elucidate the fundamental relationship between processing, structure, and properties of these polyesters derived from natural feedstocks. Key considerations include the methodologies by which feedstocks are sourced, separated, and subsequently translated into useful polymers. Ultimately, knowledge gained will provide impetus for and education in the transformation of bio-refined products into macromolecules that meet the diverse needs of society.

Specific objectives target a fundamental understanding of the processing-structure-property relationships of bio-based polymers derived from green separation techniques. The project will holistically consider the choice of feedstock, extraction technique, polymer synthesis, and polymer degradation to ultimately produce environmentally sustainable processes and products. An iterative approach will use sustainability metrics throughout and will evaluate these metrics to determine the overall process viability from economic and environmental perspectives. By integrating process sustainability metrics into traditional processing-structure-property relationship methodology used in polymer development, the approach will shift the conventional polymer design paradigm to comprehensively address both polymer function and sustainability via the following interconnected, concurrent aims: (I) Leverage green solvent extraction to produce enriched monomer fractions from renewable feedstocks, (II) Sustainably develop polyester thermoplastics and thermosets derived from fractionated biomass, and (III) Evaluate process technoeconomic and life cycle sustainability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This project sought to utilize residual biomass sources, green extraction techniques, and appropriate polymer syntheses to incorporate structurally rigid monomers (i.e., pentacyclic triterpenoids) into the backbones of thermoplastic and thermosetting polyesters and elucidate the fundamental relationships between processing, structure, and properties of these polyesters.  Our holistic approach considered feedstock choice, extraction technique, and polymer synthesis routes to ultimately produce potentially environmentally sustainable processes and products.  We focused on birch bark extracts (BBEs) as our feedstock of choice with extraction techniques that utilized green solvents with mild temperatures.  Upon drying, such BBEs were utilized directly in the synthesis of thermosetting polyesters.  Betulin, a pentacyclic triterpenoid, that (1) can be extracted from birch bark in high yields and (2) has a structure that enables facile incorporation into polymer backbones via direct reactions with its hydroxyl moieties, was copolymerized with other bio-derived monomers, e.g., glycerol, itaconic acid, and 1,12-dodecanedioc acid, in the synthesis of thermoplastic and thermosetting polyesters.

The molecular weights and polymer properties of the betulin-containing thermoplastic polyesters were controlled via the time, temperature, and comonomer type(s) employed in their syntheses.  Similarly, the betulin-containing thermosetting polyesters, in partnership with our collaborators at Lafayette College, were prepared with polymer properties influenced by comonomer type(s) and the betulin to comonomer ratios employed.  Furthermore, with our Lafayette College collaborators, polymer properties were controlled depending on the birch bark extraction methods utilized as well as the comonomer type(s) and BBE to comonomer ratios employed.  Results of the synthesized polymers that contained itaconic acid were published in ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering.  Lastly, with our Lafayette College collaborators, degradation studies and economic and life cycle metrics indicated that the synthesized polyesters may degrade in the environment after use and that the overall production of the polyesters were promising with low E-factor, high renewability, and potential for competitive selling prices attributes, respectively.  However, energy optimization and solvent recovery strategies are recommended during scale-up of the overall processes.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

During the four year grant period, three faculty, four graduate students, and twenty undergraduate students at Rowan University worked collaboratively together, as well as with faculty and students at Lafayette College, on literature reviews, research techniques, experimental data analyses, and scientific communications.  During the academic semesters, the undergraduate students worked closely together and with the faculty and graduate students via Rowan’s Junior-Senior Engineering Clinic courses.  Our Making Awesome Stuff from Birch Bark Clinic project ran each semester all four years and provided both the graduate and undergraduate students an immersive research and teaching experience.  Furthermore, at least one undergraduate student continued to work on the project as a part of their internship opportunity each summer.  These experiences have led to one PhD student pursing a career in sustainability at the US EPA, one PhD student conducting a postdoctoral research fellowship at a midwestern university working on another NSF funded, sustainability focused grant, and six undergraduates continuing their education by pursing graduate degrees in the fields of sustainability and/or polymers.

 

As a part of this grant opportunity, we connected our work to agriculture, forestry, ecology, environmental science, chemistry, pharmacology, cosmetics, and health care.  We accomplished this through our birch tree farm initiative here at Rowan University.  The Advanced Materials & Manufacturing Institute (AMMI) at Rowan University planted 200 river birch trees on Rowan’s developing west campus as well as formed a Birch Tree Farm Steering Committee that consists of faculty and graduate students from chemistry, chemical engineering, biology, and environmental science.  The farm is enabling cross-cutting research for bio-based plastics, coatings, and pharmaceuticals, along with unique experiential learning experiences for enthusiastic, goal-driven undergraduate and graduate students.

Furthermore, green chemistry & engineering concepts and examples, much derived by the research being conducted as part of this grant, were woven into senior- and graduate-level polymer science & engineering courses and foundational chemical engineering undergraduate courses, impacting over 150 students.

This project increased research infrastructure at Rowan University through the purchase of dedicated polycondensation laboratory equipment, expanding our capabilities to synthesize polymers with controlled molecular weights and molecular weight distributions.

Three faculty members at two PUIs strengthened their interdisciplinary research collaboration through this grant opportunity.  Together, we hosted a symposium on the Sustainable Production of Biobased Polymers for three consecutive years at the 2021-2023 ACS Green Chemistry & Engineering Conference.  Our students benefited greatly and had multiple opportunities for professional development at group meetings, site visits, and poster and podium presentations at internal, regional, and national conferences.

Through the conferences that we have attended, the project made an impact beyond the bounds of science, engineering, and the academic world through the dissemination of knowledge and discussion of not only technology related to the sustainable production of biobased polymers but also public perceptions, public behavior, public policy, and the drivers needed to foster appropriate and meaningful change.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2024
Modified by: Joseph F Stanzione
